About 30 years ago, I left Cuba for the United States with my son who started learning in a kindergarten there. Several weeks  _  , my son's teacher asked me to meet him at the school. In the office , after the greeting words, the teacher asked "Is your son mentally retarded ?" Was he talking about my wonderful Scola? NO, no, it _ be. What a helpless, _  moment! I told him that Scola was a quiet, sweet little boy. I asked him  _ he was asking me this question. Didn't he know my son did not speak English yet?
He was _ ,"Why haven't you taught him to speak English? Don't you speak English at home?"
"No, I didn't speak English at home," I replied, "I was sure my son would learn English in a few months, and I didn't want him  to forget his native language."
"I can't believe  _ there are such people who don't teach their children to speak English at home and at all time." the teacher said.
Then he told me the meeting was over, and I _ the office.
As I had expected,  my son  learned to speak English well before the school year was over. He went on to graduate from college and got a high-paid job. He travels widely and has a _ life. And all these are mostly because of being bilingual .
Speaking more than one language allows people to communicate with  others ;it teaches people about other cultures and other places. But the "educator" I met in my son's kindergarten didn't realized these.
